properties.description: This tour is a visualized map of crowdsourced Boston places of intersts - a tour for locals, newcomers alike. All text, images, descriptions are taken from Secret Boston.

Start from Ashmont station, easily accessible off of the Red Line or bus transit. Take the Mattapan Trolley, the oldest trolley train in Massachusettes and the only train to run through a cemetary in the country. Take a walk/bike along Boston's forgotten river, the Neponset, on a trail that will eventually connect Blue Hills with Castle Island (also runs parallel to Mattapan high speed line for several miles). The trolley begins running from 5:17AM, so you're free to give your day an early start. This is an excellent way to experience several different modes of Boston transportation and see how the city is preserving the historic with modern functionality

It remains important to visit the North End, one of Boston's oldest neighborhoods and bear witness to its ongoing evolution. This little hole in the wall cafe blends right into the brickwork, with an unassming storefront and tiny sign.

Open Monday-Saturday 11am, they tend to run out of pizza quick, so you'll want to stop by as soon as you can!

properties.chapter: 3) Afternoon walk: Victory Gardens near Fenway
properties.description: Fenway Victory Gardens is a part of the famous "Emerald Necklace" of parks originally designed by Frederick Olmsted. These are the oldest WWII Victory Gardens in the United States, with over 500 gardens and about 7.5 acres. Say hi to some residents and owners of the gardens and walk over to Newbury Street for some shopping after.

properties.chapter: 4) Kick up Memories: Adidas Runbase store/mini museum
properties.description: The Boston Marathon has it's own museum, in a way. The Boston Marathon was run for the first time in 1897, only one year after a man from the Boston Athletic Association had competed in the first Olympics in Greece. At this Adidas RunBase store on Boylston street you can find some really cool running paraphernalia (maps, photos, sneakers etc.) from some of the first runners and some recent ones too. The store also offers tons of workout classes and a running club for the more sweat-savvy. After the resilience showed by the city coming together after the marathon bombings, this is a natural way to be a part of that history and fortitude, even if you don't feel up for running 26 miles!

Massachusetts College of Art and Design in Boston Professor Matthew Hincman installed this small, covert memorial - a relief of a fallen hoodie sweatshirt. Hincman purposely juxtoposed this memorial with the West Roxbury Civil War monument in the same square. "Still, 2014" honors the unarmed black teenager shot in 2012 whose death sparked national outrage and dialogue and the nation-wide Black Lives Matter Movement. After a moment at this memorial, visit the other art installation that Hincman is most known for - a guerilla-installed bench around Jamaica Ponds, another member of the string of Emerald Necklace Conservatory parks. After a series of guerilla installations, Hincman is commissioned by the City to create another work of art for the Jamaica Plan Library.

properties.chapter: 6) Turning Time: Ferris Wheels Bike Shop
properties.description: Take a spin at the Ferris Wheel Bicycle Shop! Jeffrey Ferris who owns iconic Ferris Wheels Bike Shop in JP is 6th cousin twice removed of George Washington Ferris they guy who invented the Ferris Wheel in 1890. It debuted in 1893 at Chicago World's Fair. If you're just passing through and can't buy a bike here, you can pick up a Blue Bike nearby at the Curtis Hall Blue Bike dock at South adn Center.

Boston's plethora of academic instituions help enrich the city fabric, and BU's Coit Observatory invites the public to explore beyond the atmosphre. On Wednesday nights, Coit hosts open observatories that invite aspiring astronomers to aim different lenses at the night sky. It opens at 7:30 during the fall and winter, and at 8:30 during the spring and summer. Call ahead because it is weather permitting and tickets are suggested since it constantly sells out (free tickets!). A great way to end the night.
